entry.title: Prynth at Sónar 2018
entry.content:
Heading to Barcelona for Sónar 2018, where we’ll be showing Prynth at Sónar+D Marketlab, together with Music Motion Alliance. Come visit us on our booth to get to know more about Prynth or just play with the Mitt.

Music Motion Alliance
entry.summary: Heading to Barcelona for Sónar 2018, where we’ll be showing Prynth at Sónar+D Marketlab, together with Music Motion Alliance. Come visit us on our booth to get to know more about Prynth or just play with the Mitt.

entry.title: Prynth v05 Image 2018-06-07 Update
entry.content:
The Prynth v05 image has been updated (2018-06–07) to fix a couple of issues:

. This image should now work with the Raspberry Pi 3B+.

. The Prynth server could malfunction due to some sclang errors that weren’t being handled properly.

The new image can be found at:

https://prynth.github.io/create/downloads.html
entry.summary: The Prynth v05 image has been updated (2018-06–07) to fix a couple of issues:

entry.title: Prynth version 0.5 released!
entry.content:
Prynth v0.5 is here, with many new features, bug fixes and revised documentation.

New features:

Fully redesigned sensor acquisition system:
. Sampling rate control
. Sensor masking.
. Sensor data monitoring.
. Customizable OSC addressing
. High and low resolutions (1 byte or 4 bytes floats).
. Data filtering per sensor, directly on the Teensy and with choices of lowpass filter, 1€ filter and Schmitt trigger.
. Message acknowledgement and integrity check.

Hardware:
. Fully redesigned PCBs.
. Digital sensors over I2C and SPI.
. Digital IO pins.

SuperCollider editor:
. Syntax colorizing
. Execute code within parenthesis, a la SuperCollider.
. Resizable post window.

Documentation and website revision

As always, report any bugs in our forum and let us know about your creations with Prynth.
entry.summary: Prynth v0.5 is here, with many new features, bug fixes and revised documentation.

entry.title: News
entry.content:
It’s been a while since there was news from Prynth, but although quiet we’ve continued hard at work in our evil machinations.

In September last year we launched an experimental beta 0.4 distro, that incorporated just-in-time compiling capabilities, so that SuperCollider programs could executed on-the-fly. Since then we talked to several Prynth users and found key areas were we could make it better, thus deciding to take our time to make a new major revision in both hardware and software.

We are currently planning on a March release and the expected goodies include:

  • Just-in-time compiling.
  • Automatic execution of code blocks a la SuperCollider.
  • Better management of Post window and errors.
  • All new Muxi Control board, with I2C and SPI for digital devices.
  • Full Serial RX/TX between SuperCollider and the Teensy.
  • New sensor filtering implementation, based on the one euro filter by Casiez and team.
  • Updated versions of Debian, SuperCollider and Node JS modules.
  • Bug crushing.

We’d also like to take the opportunity to welcome Ajin Tom and Harish Venkatesan, who have joined the team to help in the development of this new release.

As always, if you have any suggestions, bug reports or instruments to show us, use the contacts on the webpage (prynth.github.io).

Stay tuned!
entry.summary: It’s been a while since there was news from Prynth, but although quiet we’ve continued hard at work in our evil machinations.

entry.title: RR
entry.content:
Created by Daniel Górny, we just received word from RR, a special take the crossover between the physical patching paradigm and digital synthesis with Prynth. Check out RR on the instrument gallery.

NOTE: Let us know if you’ve developed a new instrument with Prynth!
entry.summary: Created by Daniel Górny, we just received word from RR, a special take the crossover between the physical patching paradigm and digital synthesis with Prynth. Check out RR on the instrument gallery.

entry.title: Prynth v. 0.4 beta now available
entry.content:
Today we are happy to announce the release of the Prynth v0.4 beta software. It includes several new features but the most important one is true JIT, which is one of the main features of SuperCollider as an interactive programming language. You can now execute blocks of code in realtime, which is particularly useful when implementing and testing your Prynth instrument.

What’s new:

  • JIT compiling - select a line or a block of code and run it using the standard SuperCollider execute shortcuts (“Cmd + Enter” or “Ctrl+Enter”, depending on your browser OS)
  • Stop audio processing using “Cmd + .”
  • Sensor data can now be sent to either server or language.
  • Editor more fine-tuned for code editing (eg. parenthesis matching).
  • Revamped file management panels.
  • New system panel with settings for WIFI connection, hostname, default file to run on startup, sensor data target and audio device settings (device number, vector size, sample rate).
  • Restart SC and JACK directly via Prynth Editor.
  • Post window now scrolls properly.
  • Improved window resizing.

This is a software update only and distributed as a new Raspbian modified distro. To use it you can follow the same instructions as with the previous version. Head on to the downloads page and remember to backup your SuperCollider programs. This is a beta pre-release version, so it could contain bugs. Please report back if you find any of you have any suggestions.
entry.summary: Today we are happy to announce the release of the Prynth v0.4 beta software. It includes several new features but the most important one is true JIT, which is one of the main features of SuperCollider as an interactive programming language. You can now execute blocks of code in realtime, which is particularly useful when implementing and testing your Prynth instrument.

entry.title: Towards JIT in Prynth
entry.content:
One of the greatest strengths of SuperCollider is its ability to perform just-in-time compiling, where it’s possible to inject new code while the main program keeps running. This makes SuperCollider an excellent language for interactive coding, because it is possible to try new ideas and perform them instantly, without any interruption of audio or logic process.

In the previous version of Prynth this feature wasn’t present, because the web-based code editor would send a full chunk of code to the Raspberry Pi and tell it to re-initialize SuperCollider running that code. This is about to change with version 0.4, which integrates the excellent Node.js library developed by Crucial Felix.

In the new version you’ll be able to simultaneously code and play your Prynth instrument. There are also substantial improvements in file management and system settings. Stay tuned for the beta version coming pretty soon.
entry.summary: One of the greatest strengths of SuperCollider is its ability to perform just-in-time compiling, where it’s possible to inject new code while the main program keeps running. This makes SuperCollider an excellent language for interactive coding, because it is possible to try new ideas and perform them instantly, without any interruption of audio or logic process.

entry.title: The Sonio Soundboard
entry.content:
Check out the SONIO soundboard, a Prynth-based collaborative music making device, developed by Tim Kong, Karen Cancino & Marc St. Pierre. Participants described the board as having a ‘futuristic’ feel, where the overall theme and for the sound and visuals was inspired by science fiction movies like Star Wars and Close Encounters of the Third Kind.

https://prynth.github.io/instruments/soundboard/

NOTE: If you’ve developed a new Prynth instrument, please let us know so we can feature it in our gallery.
entry.summary: Check out the SONIO soundboard, a Prynth-based collaborative music making device, developed by Tim Kong, Karen Cancino & Marc St. Pierre. Participants described the board as having a ‘futuristic’ feel, where the overall theme and for the sound and visuals was inspired by science fiction movies like Star Wars and Close Encounters of the Third Kind.

entry.title: Upcoming Events
entry.content:
Next week I will be presenting Prynth at two events in Montreal. The first is at the Montreal Raspberry Pi users gathering, organized by Club Fambroise and District 3 Innovation Center. The second is “Lutherie numérique & Nouvelles Interfaces Musicales” organized by MusicMotion Alliance & CIRMMT. Both events require signup with eventbrite. It’s also a good time to remind that the application dates for the Enterface 17 workshop in Porto are closing soon.

April 26th, 6:30pm - Rencontre des utilisateurs de Raspberry Pi du grand Montréal

April 27th, 6:00pm - Lutherie numérique & Nouvelles Interfaces Musicales
entry.summary: Next week I will be presenting Prynth at two events in Montreal. The first is at the Montreal Raspberry Pi users gathering, organized by Club Fambroise and District 3 Innovation Center. The second is “Lutherie numérique & Nouvelles Interfaces Musicales” organized by MusicMotion Alliance & CIRMMT. Both events require signup with eventbrite. It’s also a good time to remind that the application dates for the Enterface 17 workshop in Porto are closing soon.

entry.title: Enterface 17 Call
entry.content:
Looking forward to summertime building synths in sunny Portugal? I am pleased to announce a Prynth workshop as part of Enterface 17 (the 13th International Summer Workshop on Multimodal Interfaces), which will happen during the first two weeks of July in Porto (Portugal).

While there are several other Prynth workshops in the planning, this one won’t be dedicated solely to DIY. We will definitely build our own synths but we plan on also creating a knowledge sharing group to discuss theories on interfaces between musician and performance device.

We mainly invite electronic musicians with electronics and programming chops but it would be great if there were any cognitive psychology gurus out there interested in tackling these questions and working with the group towards different perspectives and knowledge areas. Ideally by the end of the workshop we would have results leading to academic publication.

To apply for participation head over to: http://artes.ucp.pt/enterface17/

Applications open until April 21st.
entry.summary: Looking forward to summertime building synths in sunny Portugal? I am pleased to announce a Prynth workshop as part of Enterface 17 (the 13th International Summer Workshop on Multimodal Interfaces), which will happen during the first two weeks of July in Porto (Portugal).
